text: Sunlight filtered through the wooden lattice windows, spilling across the counter. The air still carried the warmth of last night’s hearth, so still it made time feel suspended.
I was tallying up the unpaid bills from the previous night when a soft knock came from the door.
“Good morning.”
It was Alicia. She had taken off her armor and wore a light brown outfit suited for travel. The cracked sword at her waist still hung quietly by her side—like an extension of her body.
“It’s Sunday, isn’t it? The inn’s closed today?”
I nodded.
“Perfect,” she smiled. “Come with me to the market—I need to pick up a few things.”
“Me?” I blinked in surprise.
I hesitated, glancing out the window. The morning breeze was still cold, and a thin mist swallowed the forest line in the distance.
“There’ve been beasts sighted outside town lately,” I said quietly. “A hunter mentioned it just yesterday.”
“All the better,” she replied calmly. “If we meet one, someone needs to deal with it.”
Her lips curved slightly, as if to reassure me—or perhaps because danger had become too ordinary to her.
“What about Lucia? Isn’t she coming?”
“She was sorting herbs late last night. She’s probably still asleep.”
She paused before adding softly, “Let her rest a bit longer. The poor girl was exhausted.”
I sighed, took off my apron, and reached for my coat.
To the east of town stretched a winding stone path flanked by thawing pine trees. The air was damp, and the distant sound of running water echoed faintly.
Alicia walked ahead with a steady stride, occasionally glancing back at me. Sunlight filtered through the branches, tracing golden lines across her shoulders.
“You always take this road?”
“Yeah. I don’t go out much, but I remember this route well. Whenever the wine runs out, I have to head into town for supplies.”
“You really do live a lonely life.”
Her tone was casual, almost teasing—but her steps slowed for a brief moment, as if she were listening to the wind.
A deep growl rumbled through the forest the next second.
The ground quaked violently, scattering dead leaves. A beast covered in rocky plates burst from the earth, its eyes burning with a sickly green light.
Before I could react, it lunged toward us—the air reeking of blood and iron!
